turn.2: Free-form deformation In computer graphics, free-form deformation (FFD) is a geometric technique used to model simple deformations of rigid objects.
turn.4: It is based on the idea of enclosing an object within a cube or another hull object, and transforming the object within the hull as the hull is deformed.
turn.5: Is there anything else interesting about it?
turn.6: Deformation of the hull is based on the concept of so-called "hyper-patches", which are three-dimensional analogs of parametric curves such as Bézier curves, B-splines, or NURBs.
turn.8: The technique was first described by Thomas W. Sederberg and Scott R.
turn.10: Parry in 1986, and is based on an earlier technique by Alan Barr.
turn.12: It was extended by Coquillart to a technique described as "extended free-form deformation", which refines the hull object by introducing additional geometry or by using different hull objects such as cylinders and prisms.
